summary_points: 1.  Garmin's Q1 2025 net sales increased 11% year-over-year to $1,535,099,000.
2.  As of March 29, 2025, 73% of Garmin's securities portfolio was at an unrealized loss.
3. Garmin has $209,805 remaining in its share repurchase program, expiring December 26, 2026.
1. GE HealthCare's Q1 2025 net income was $564 million, a 51% year-over-year increase.
2.  New US tariffs enacted in April 2025 are expected to negatively impact GE HealthCare's financials, though the extent remains uncertain.
3. GE HealthCare anticipates $40 million in restructuring expenses over the next year (ending March 31, 2026).
1. Visa's operating expenses increased 22% year-over-year in the three months ended March 31, 2025, primarily due to a higher litigation provision.
2. Visa now has a $34.7 billion share repurchase program authorized as of April 30, 2025, with no expiration date.
3.  Visa's acquisition of Featurespace Limited in December 2024 cost $946 million, with $794 million allocated to goodwill.
1. Cadence Design Systems' revenue increased by $233.3 million (23%) year-over-year in the quarter ended March 31, 2025.
2.  Amortization expense for acquired intangibles is projected to be $68.3 million for the remainder of fiscal year 2025, based on forecasts made as of April 30, 2025.
3. Cadence is currently assessing the impact of two new accounting standards (ASU No. 2023-09 and ASU No. 2024-03) on its financial reporting.
1. Sysco's fiscal year 2025 net sales growth projection was lowered to approximately 3%, down from a previous projection of 4-5%, primarily due to lower than expected volume.
2. As of March 29, 2025, Sysco held $1.5 billion in cash and cash equivalents, but also faces a potential $131 million charge related to a tax law interpretation lawsuit.
3.  Sysco's Q3 2025 operating income and net earnings decreased by 5.7% and 5.6% respectively year-over-year, due to lower consumer confidence and adverse weather conditions.
1. Veralto Corp's net earnings increased by 22% in the three months ending April 4, 2025, compared to the same period in 2024.
2.  U.S. government tariffs pose a new risk factor, potentially increasing costs and reducing demand for Veralto's products.
3. Veralto Corp's total identifiable assets increased by $239 million between December 31, 2024, and April 4, 2025, reaching $6,645 million.
1. S&P Global Inc. will spin off its Mobility segment as a separate publicly traded company within the next 12-18 months.
2.  Q1 2025 revenue increased by 8% year-over-year to $3.777 billion.
3.  S&P Global Inc. faces ongoing legal proceedings in Australia with uncertain financial implications.
1. Booking Holdings' Q1 2025 net income decreased significantly to $333 million from $776 million in Q1 2024.

2.  Despite 7.2% year-over-year growth in total gross bookings,  Booking Holdings widened its full-year 2025 growth forecast range due to increased geopolitical and macroeconomic uncertainty (as of April 30, 2025).
3.  Booking.com's April 2025 bank guarantee arrangement related to a suspended Spanish fine presents a potential future financial risk.
1. Yum! Brands reported first-quarter 2025 GAAP EPS of $0.90 and EPS excluding special items of $1.30, a 13% year-over-year increase.
2.  While worldwide system sales grew 5% (excluding foreign currency translation),  Pizza Hut Division system sales decreased by 4% year-over-year.
3. David Gibbs, Yum!'s CEO, announced his intention to retire in the first quarter of 2026.
1. Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings Ltd. reported a GAAP net loss of ($40.3) million for the quarter ended March 31, 2025, a $57.6 million decrease compared to the first quarter of 2024.

2.  Despite a ~3% decrease in total revenue year-over-year, primarily due to reduced Capacity Days and foreign exchange losses, the company exceeded its Adjusted EBITDA guidance for Q1 2025, reaching $453 million.

3. Full-year 2025 Adjusted EBITDA and Adjusted EPS guidance remains unchanged at approximately $2.72 billion and $2.05 respectively, despite downward revisions to Net Yield and Adjusted Net Cruise Cost Excluding Fuel guidance as of April 30, 2025.
1. Garmin Ltd. reported record first-quarter 2025 consolidated revenue of $1.54 billion, an 11% increase year-over-year.
2. The Outdoor segment experienced the most significant year-over-year revenue growth at 20%, driven by increased demand for adventure watches.
3.  Garmin Ltd. is maintaining its full-year 2025 pro forma EPS guidance of $7.80, despite updating its revenue expectations to approximately $6.85 billion, as of April 30, 2025.

1. Martin Marietta Materials, Inc. reported a significant year-over-year (YoY) decrease in earnings from operations, net earnings, and earnings per diluted share for the first quarter ended March 31, 2025, compared to the first quarter of 2024, despite increased revenues and gross profit.
2.  As of March 31, 2025, Martin Marietta had $101 million of cash and cash equivalents and $1.2 billion of unused borrowing capacity.
3. Martin Marietta expects IIJA contributions to peak in 2026, followed by a typical tail thereafter, and anticipates that the successor bill to the IIJA may prioritize aggregates-intensive projects.
1. In the third quarter ended March 31, 2025, ADP's revenues increased 6% year-over-year to $5.6 billion, while net earnings and adjusted net earnings both increased 5% to $1.2 billion.
2.  ADP raised its full-year 2025 guidance for adjusted diluted EPS growth to 8-9% and adjusted EBIT margin expansion to 40-50 basis points as of April 30, 2025.

3. The interest on funds held for clients is projected to be $1.160 to $1.170 billion in fiscal year 2025, based on anticipated growth in client funds balances of 5% to 6% and an average yield increase to 3.1%.
1. Peter J. Hadley was appointed CFO of Automatic Data Processing, Inc., effective July 1, 2025, succeeding Don McGuire, who will remain in a transition role until September 30, 2025.
2. Mr. Hadley's total target equity award value for fiscal year 2026 is expected to be $4,875,000.

3.  Mr. Hadley's employment agreement includes an 18-month salary continuation upon involuntary termination without cause, a prorated bonus, and continued vesting in unvested equity awards for that period.
1. Caterpillar Inc.'s first-quarter 2025 sales dropped 10% year-over-year to $14.2 billion, primarily due to lower sales volume and unfavorable pricing.
2.  First-quarter 2025 profit per share significantly decreased to $4.20 from $5.75 in Q1 2024.
3.  Decreased sales volume, stemming from dealer inventory adjustments, negatively impacted future sales projections as of April 30, 2025.
1. GE HealthCare announced a new $1 billion share repurchase program on April 30, 2025.
2. First-quarter 2025 EPS increased 51% year-over-year to $1.23, while free cash flow decreased 64% to $98 million.
3. Full-year 2025 adjusted EPS guidance was lowered to $3.90-$4.10, a 9-13% year-over-year decrease, partly due to $0.85 per share in tariffs.
1. Stanley Black & Decker's first-quarter 2025 revenue was $3.7 billion, a 3% decrease year-over-year, although organic growth was 1%, offset by currency and divestitures.

2.  First-quarter 2025 gross margin increased by 130 basis points year-over-year to 29.9%, primarily due to supply chain efficiencies and new product launches, partially offset by inflation and tariffs.
3.  Tariffs are projected to negatively impact 2025 EPS by approximately $0.75, net of price increases and supply chain adjustments planned for the next 12-24 months.
1. Humana revised its GAAP EPS guidance for fiscal year 2025 to approximately $14.68 from approximately $15.88, while affirming its Adjusted EPS guidance of approximately $16.25.
2.  Humana's first-quarter 2025 adjusted EPS of $11.58 exceeded expectations, primarily due to a shift in the timing of administrative expenses and investments, and CenterWell outperformance.

3. Humana anticipates a decline of approximately 550,000 individual Medicare Advantage members in 2025, resulting from exiting unprofitable plans and counties, but remains confident in its pricing strategy.

1. Generac Holdings Inc.'s Q1 2025 net sales increased 6% year-over-year to $942 million, driven by a 15% rise in residential product sales, while commercial and industrial product sales decreased by 5%.
2.  Adjusted net income attributable to the company in Q1 2025 was $75 million ($1.26 per share), compared to $53 million ($0.88 per share) in Q1 2024.

3.  Generac lowered its full-year 2025 net sales growth guidance to 0-7% (previously 3-7%) due to higher tariffs, uncertain government policies, and macroeconomic uncertainty;  the adjusted EBITDA margin guidance was also lowered to 17.0-19.0% (previously 18.0-19.0%).
1. Trane Technologies plc reported strong first-quarter 2025 results, with reported revenues up 11% year-over-year to $4.7 billion and adjusted continuing EPS up 26% to $2.45.

2.  The Americas segment significantly outperformed other segments, showing 14% year-over-year revenue growth (13% organic), compared to 4% growth in EMEA (6% organic) and a 4% decline in Asia Pacific (3% organic).

3.  Trane Technologies reaffirmed its full-year 2025 guidance, expecting revenue growth of approximately 7.5% to 8.5% and adjusted continuing EPS of $12.70 to $12.90,  and anticipates performing towards the high end of this range.
1. News Corp repurchased approximately US$666,820,338.78 worth of Class A and Class B shares as of April 29, 2025, under a US$1 billion stock repurchase program.
2.  On April 29, 2025,  21,678,049 Class A shares and 10,699,797 Class B shares were repurchased, totaling US$666,820,338.78.
3. News Corp's future share repurchases are subject to market conditions, the market price of its stock, and other factors, and no ASX-listed CDIs will be repurchased in this program.

1. As of March 31, 2025, Edison International completed over 6,450 miles of covered conductor and over 2.5 million trims and removals in high fire-risk areas, resulting in zero ignitions from covered conductor failure.
2. Edison International projects a 6-8% compound annual growth rate in its rate base from 2023 to 2028.
3.  Edison International's April 29, 2025, business update highlighted significant risks related to wildfire liability, cybersecurity, and grid infrastructure upgrades.
